SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: To provide equality of cancer care to rural patients, Townsville Cancer Centre (TCC) administers intensive chemotherapy regimens to rural patients with node positive breast and metastatic colorectal cancers at the same doses as urban patients
Side effects were usually managed by rural general practitioners locally
AIM: The aim is to determine the safety of this practice by comparing the profile of serious adverse events and dose intensities between urban and rural patients at the TCC
METHOD: A retrospective audit was conducted in patients with metastatic colorectal and node positive breast cancers during a 24 month period
Fisher exact test was used for analysis
Rurality was determined as per rural, remote and metropolitan classification
RESULTS: Of the 121 patients included, 70 and 51 patients had breast and colon cancers respectively
The urban versus rural patient split amongst all patients, breast and colorectal cancer subgroups was 68 vs 53, 43 vs 27 and 25 vs 26 respectively
A total of 421 cycles were given with dose intensity of >95% for breast cancer in both groups (p>0.05)
Rate of febrile neutropenia was 9.3% vs 7.4% (p=0.56)
For XELOX, rate of diarrhoea was 20% vs 19% (p=0.66) and rate of vomiting was 20% vs 11% (p=0.11)
Only 2 patients were transferred to Townsville for admission
No toxic death occurred in either group
CONCLUSION: It appears safe to administer intensive chemotherapy regimens at standard doses to rural patients without increased morbidity or mortality
Support for general practitioners via phone or videoconferencing may reduce the safety concerns
